title: Dual Threat Dilemma
text:
In 2018, the Baltimore Ravens took a chance picking Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson with the 32 overall pick in the NFL Draft. Jackson, a Heisman-Trophy winning dual-threat quarterback, who dazzled fans by running the ball better than he threw it. Drafting Jackson was an interesting pick, because the Ravens would have to revamp their entire offense around his interesting skill set and get rid of The GOAT Joe Flacco. During his first year on the Ravens, Jackson took over the offense and lit up the field. During his rookie contract he managed to have a 74-27 record in the regular season, however, injuries kept him sidelined for the end of the 2021 and 2022 seasons. The Ravens had a hard decision to make with the concerns of the longevity of Jackson’s career and paying a running back quarterback money. Throughout the contract negotiations Jackson had requested to be traded and the Ravens placed a non-exclusive franchise tag on him to try and get other teams to essentially make a market for Jackson. That didn’t work because no one wanted him and the market was over inflated because of massage enthusiast Deshaun Watson’s horrible fully guaranteed contract that the Cleveland Browns signed. The Ravens eventually paid Jackson, but did they make the right decision or was there a better answer? The choice was made even harder having the best backup quarterback in the NFL, Tyler Snoop Huntley who the Ravens let walk to the Dolphins. Lets look at some data (https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2023/passing.htm https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2023/scrimmage.htm) and NFL Salaries (https://overthecap.com/position/quarterback).


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)
library(patchwork)
library(waffle)

pass<-read_csv("NFLPass24.csv")

QB <- pass |>
  filter(Pos=="QB") |>
  filter(G>1) |>
  filter(Cash>1) |>
  filter(QBR>10) |>
  filter(Yds>=1) 

YPG <- QB |> 
  group_by(Player, Team, G, QBR, Cash, TD, Int,Yds) |>
  summarise(
    YardsPerGame = Yds/G,
CashPerGame = Cash/G
)

TH <-YPG|>
  filter(Player == "Tyler Huntley")

LJ <-YPG |>
  filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

BP<-YPG |>
  filter(Player =="Brock Purdy")

JB<-YPG |>
  filter(Player =="Joe Burrow")

KT<-YPG |>
  filter(Player =="Kyle Trask") 

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=YPG, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="darkgrey", alpha=.3) + geom_point(data=JB, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="orange" ) +
geom_text_repel(data=JB, aes(x=YardsPerGame+65, y=QBR, label=Player)) +
geom_point(data=TH, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="cyan" ) +
  geom_text_repel(data=TH, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, label=Player)) +
  geom_point(data=LJ, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="purple" ) +
  geom_text_repel(data=LJ, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, label=Player)) +
   geom_point(data=BP, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="red" )+
  geom_text_repel(data=BP, aes(x=YardsPerGame+10, y=QBR, label=Player)) +
  geom_point(data=KT, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, size=Cash), color="darkred" ) +
geom_text_repel(data=KT, aes(x=YardsPerGame, y=QBR, label=Player))+
geom_vline(xintercept = 160.8224) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 51.01143  ) +
  scale_size_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  theme_minimal()+ 
  labs(
    x="Passing Yards Per Game", 
    y="Average Quarterback Rating", 
    title="Things did not go swimmingly for the new Dolphin", 
    subtitle="Tyler Huntley is a below average quarterback. Joe Burrow and Lamar Jackson stood out as top \nquarterbacks. Brock Purdy is balling out on a budget, while Kyle Trask is more like Kyle Trash.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference and Over The Cap  | By Joshua Carlson",
size = "$alary"
    )  + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot")









The bubble chart shows the relationship between the average passing yards per game and average quarterback rating with salary spent for the 2024 season. Tyler Huntley (cyan) was the backup in Miami, but due to injuries he got his chance to prove why the Ravens were wrong. In his five games he proved to be the most mediocre quarterback and makes me regret every take I have ever had. Especially since Lamar Jackson (purple) is above average in both metrics. The only downside is the original problem; his bubble is way larger than Huntley’s. Well, how does Lamar compare to other quarterbacks in his price range? Fellow AFC North quarterback, Joe Burrow had a slightly worse QBR but averaged more yards. What about Huntley? Mr. Irrelevant, Brock Purdy proved that you didn’t have to make money to be a good quarterback and that Tyler Huntley was actually not the bargain the Ravens were looking for. Who was the worst quarterback per dollar? Kyle Trask AKA Kyle Trash played four games for the Buccaneers and only gained five yards. For a whopping $352,248.60 per yard.


Code
Scrim <- read_csv("NFLScrim24.csv")|>
  filter(Pos=="QB") |>
  mutate(
    RushTDG = RushTD/G,
    FmbG= Fmb/G
  ) 

LJR <- Scrim |>
  filter(Player=="Lamar Jackson")

THR <- Scrim |>
  filter(Player=="Tyler Huntley")
  
Yds <-Scrim |>
  top_n(15, wt=`RushY/G`)

  TD <-Scrim |>
  top_n(15, wt=RushTDG)
  
  
  Ydsbar<- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=Yds, aes(x=reorder(Player, `RushY/G`), weight=`RushY/G`)) +
    geom_bar(data=LJR, aes(x=reorder(Player, `RushY/G`), weight=`RushY/G`), fill="purple") +
    geom_bar(data=THR, aes(x=reorder(Player, `RushY/G`), weight=`RushY/G`), fill="cyan") +
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(
    x="Rushing yards per game", 
    y="", 
    title="Running the football is what they do the best", 
    subtitle="Lamar Jackson leads quartbacks in rushing yards per game and Tyler Huntley is top 15"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 

TDbar<- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=TD, aes(x=reorder(Player, RushTDG), weight=RushTDG)) +
  geom_bar(data=LJR, aes(x=reorder(Player, RushTDG), weight=RushTDG), fill="purple") +
  geom_bar(data=THR, aes(x=reorder(Player, RushTDG), weight=RushTDG), fill="cyan") +
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="Rushing touchdowns pre game", 
    y="", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Joshua Carlson"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 

Ydsbar + TDbar









It wouldn’t be fair to judge these quarterbacks without looking at their legs. To no one’s surprise if you put a running back at quarterback, he’s going to lead quarterbacks in rushing yards per game. Tyler Huntley was also able to make the top 15 but almost averaged half as many yards. On the other hand, he was better at scoring rushing touchdowns than Jackson. So maybe the Ravens should have stuck with Huntley.


Code
THI <- c("Interceptions"=3, "Fumbles"=6, 5)
LJI <- c("Interceptions"=4, "Fumbles"=10)

iron(
 waffle(LJI, 
        rows = 2, 
   colors = c("black", "purple")) + 
   labs(
     x="Lamar Jackson Turnovers",
     title="The problems when you put a running back at quarterback", 
     subtitle="Lamar Jackson learned to keep it clean and Tyler Huntley is a turnover machine.") + 
   theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  ),
 waffle(THI, 
        rows = 2,
   colors = c("black", "cyan", "white")) +
   labs(
     x = "Tyler Huntley Turnovers\n1 square = 1 turnover",
     caption="Source: Sports Reference | Graphic by Joshua Carlson"
     )
) 









I regret everything I have ever said, and the entire project was a waste of time. Tyler Huntley managed to turn over the ball nine times in five games, only five fewer than Lamar did the entire season. Also, Lamar won his second MVP with 5,087 total scrimmage yards and 45 combined touchdowns. Not only was he a great running back, but Lamar actually learned how to throw the ball. Not much has changed today. After a few stops, Tyler Huntley is back with the Ravens as a backup, Lamar is still the clear starter with another bag on the way, and the Ravens still can’t win in the playoffs.

title: nfl commongami
text:
A scorigami is a final score that has never happened before. This is exciting in the NFL because scoring can happen in several ways: touchdowns (6 points), field goals (3 points), Point After Touchdowns (1 or 2 points), and safeties (2 points). Football math makes it harder for there to be many different final scores because teams often score in odd-number combinations and scoring doesn’t happen as frequently as in other sports. But what about the opposite of a scorigami? You could call it a “commongami,” meaning the most common final score in the league.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)
library(gt)
library(ggalt)
library(lubridate)

`2025` <- read_csv("2025scores.csv")

scorecount<-`2025`|> group_by(Score)|>
  tally(sort=TRUE)|>
  filter(n>2)

scorecount|>
  gt()|>
  cols_label(
    n = "Commonality of the Score"
  )|>
  tab_header(
    title = "Three scores have happened five times in 2025",
    subtitle = "The scores 23–20, 27–20, and 27–24 have been the final scores in five games each this year. "
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Joshua Carlson  |  **Source:** The Football Database")
  )|>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   )|>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = n == "5")
  )

Through Week 13 of the 2025 NFL season, there have been 194 games played with 148 different final scores. Three scores have appeared five times each: 23–20, 27–20, and 27–24.


Code
games<-read_csv("NFLGames.csv")

games100<-games|>
  filter(Count >100)

games200<-games|>
  filter(Count >200)

top<-games|>
  top_n(1, wt=Count)

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=games, aes(x=PtsW, y=PtsL, size=Count), color="lightgrey")+
  geom_point(data=games100, aes(x=PtsW, y=PtsL, size=Count), color="lightgreen")+
  geom_point(data=games200, aes(x=PtsW, y=PtsL, size=Count), color="yellow")+
  geom_point(data=top, aes(x=PtsW, y=PtsL, size=Count), color="red") +
  geom_text_repel(data=games200, aes(x=PtsW+1, y=PtsL-.3, label=Score)) + 
  theme_minimal()+ 
  labs(
    x="Winning Score", 
    y="Losing Score", 
    title="20-17 is an ordinary thing", 
    subtitle="The most common score in the NFL is 20-17 and it is not close", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference  | By Joshua Carlson",
size = "Commonality of the Score"
    )  + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot")









Throughout the entire history of the NFL, there have been 18,144 games played. The most common score ever is 20–17, which has occurred 299 times. The most recent 20–17 game came in Week 13 between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Arizona Cardinals. Two other scores have happened more than 200 times: 27–24 and 23–20. Both of those scores also ranked in the top three during the 2025 season.


Code
games2017 <-read_csv("Games2017.csv") |> 
  mutate(NewLabel = paste(`Winner/tie`, location, `Loser/tie`, "in", year(Date)))

Closest <-  games2017|>
     filter(YdsW<338,
            YdsW>323,
            YdsL<316 ,
            YdsL>301
             )

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=`games2017`, aes(x=YdsW, y=YdsL), color="lightgrey") + 
  geom_point(data=Closest, aes(x=YdsW, y=YdsL), color="red") + 
  geom_text_repel(data=Closest, aes(x=YdsW, y=YdsL, label=NewLabel)) +
geom_vline(xintercept = 330.5) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 308.5)+
  theme_minimal()+ 
  labs(
    x="Winning Team Yards", 
    y="Losing Team Yards", 
    title="Chargers and Falcons is the most common game", 
    subtitle="Of all 299 20-17 games the 2022 week 9 game between the Chargers and the Falcons is the most common.",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference  | By Joshua Carlson",
    )  + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot")









The most “typical” 20–17 game of all time, when comparing the winning and losing teams’ yards to the historical averages, occurred in Week 9 of the 2022 season between the Los Angeles Chargers and the Atlanta Falcons. The game was extremely even, with time of possession nearly split at 31 minutes to 29 minutes in favor of Atlanta. The Chargers ran 67 plays compared to the Falcons’ 60. The Falcons’ quarterback Marcus Mariota threw for only 114 yards, while the Chargers’ Justin Herbert passed for 245 yards. Both teams committed two turnovers, and the game included four lead changes.
